1.content:
Wendy Dearly is a single mom trying to manage a home with two rather independent children and a busy upward business career. She has found that being the sole parent is difficult and at most exasperating, but she loves her children and wouldn't compromise their safety or well being for all the world. Yet she must make a living to afford their home and pay all the bills associated with normal day to day living.
As her job as senior assistant to the CEO of her company, she makes a decent salary but it also affords little time to spend with Brooke or Michael, her children. She HAD spent a long time searching for the right woman to serve as their nanny while she is at work, but now nanny Mary was leaving her employment to spend time caring for own grandchildren.
Now Wendy is searching for someone to take over the care of Brooke and Michael. She had taken the day off to interview applicants sent to her by the employment agency. Several seemed ideal but none had reached that level of perfection Wendy required.
As Wendy reviewed the last applicants interview she heard giggling and laughter coming from the family room down the hall from her home office. Her children were home from school, which meant that it was sometime after 4pm. and Wendy had spent the last 6 hours interviewing.
She was about to look in to the dining room where she asked the applicants to wait when the laughter and giggling stopped.
Being a concerned mother, she knew that when children are quiet that usually means trouble. Instead of looking in the dining room she proceeded to the family room instead.
As she approached the door she heard a man's voice speaking softly.
Being suspicious of a man in her home she bounded around the corner to see a tall, lanky, red haired man sitting crossed legged on the floor, in a business suit and tie telling a story to her children. Brooke was laying on her stomach with her head in her hands and propped up on her elbows. Michael was sitting with his legs crossed same as the man in front of him.
"...then the pirates stuck a sharp sword into her back and forced her to walk the plank." the man looked up and saw Wendy and he stopped speaking.
Both Brooke and Michael turned to see what he was looking at and saw their mother in the door. Brooke ran to her mother excitedly. "Mommy, can Peter be our nanny."
"Please, Please, Please." Michael said, coming up behind his sister.
Before Wendy could respond the young man with the red hair was standing before her with his right hand extended. "My name is Peter Banting and I'm here for the position of care taker for your children."
Wendy took his hand and his handshake was that of a determined man, something that she found to be a rather distinctive of the power hungry individuals in her career. "I'm sorry, but I'm looking for someone a bit older"
"But Mommy we want Peter!" Brooke screamed.
"I'm sure you do, honey." Wendy placed her hand on Brooke's head and smoothed her soft golden hair. "But I'm looking for someone capable of discipline and take care of you when I'm not around and not someone who will play and tell you stories all day."
"Ms. Dearly, I've taken care of numerous children and I'm more than qualify." Peter says.
"I don't question your abilities but you are entirely too young to watch my children." Wendy replies.
"I'm a lot older than I look." He says putting his hands on his hips and stand with his legs shoulder width apart.
Michael goes over and stands next to Peter assuming the same stance. Then Brooke moves to stand with Peter and the three of them look at Wendy.
Finally the scene before her softens Wendy's disposition and she shakes her head. "O'k I'm out numbered. But this will only be a trial. After a week if I'm not satisfied, I let you go."
Peter kneels and puts his palm out and both children slap it as a sign of them winning over their mother.
1.title: Enter Peter

11.content:
"OK. Now where is Mary?" Wendy asks.
"When I came for my interview she was rushing out, I told her I would get Michael and Brooke. She said her grandkids needed her and she would call and explain later." Peter tells her.
"She let a total stranger pick up my kids, I thought she was more responsible than that. " Wendy says, "I guess I'll have to start dinner, now."
"I'll take care of that you go into your office and do some work, after all you wasted one day at home and things do have a way of backing up if you don't attend to them regularly." He turns to Brooke, "Brooke get your homework and meet me and Michael in the kitchen."
"Ms.Dearly. We will call you when everything is ready." Wendy looks at Peter's sparkling green eyes and suddenly feels comfortable about his caring for her children.
Brooke runs off, Wendy turns to leave and Peter and Michael head off to the kitchen.

Wendy hears giggling coming from her kitchen and she begins to wonder what Peter and the children are doing. She shuts down her computer and gets up from her soft chair to investigate. As she nears the kitchen she realizes that it's Michael who is doing all the giggling.
She looks and sees Brooke dutifully studying at the table. Michael is running around as though he's chasing and invisible bug. Peter has his back to the door as he pulls something from the oven.
Wendy is taken by his broad shoulders and thinks that Peter is quite handsome. There is something about him though that intrigues her.
"Arg, ye mates are ye ready for ye grub." Peter says imitating a pirate.
"Arrrg." Michael repeats.
"Are you ready too, Madam Dearly?" Peter asks turning to face Wendy.
If he didn't face the doorway, Wendy would have believed that he was speaking to Brooke.
She entered shyly after having her hiding place revealed.
"We're having pirate pizza." Michael proudly tells her.
"Is that right." Wendy ruffles Michaels hair. "Brooke put your books away. It's time to eat."
"I just have to finish this last one, Mother." Brooke then reads out loud. "Ok, If I have 6 apples and I want to share with two of my friends then we will get 2 apples each. Right? Two times three is six."
"Can't you say you'll make apple sauce." Peter sys as he cuts the pizza.
"Oh, Peter." Brooke says closing her book.

114.content:
Wendy never saw her children so well behaved at dinner before. Peter kept the kids entertained with a story while they ate and Wendy herself fell into his adventurous tale. When they had finished eating, all Peter did was ask for help cleaning up and both kids picked up their plates and took them to the sink.
Wendy watched as Brooke pulled over a chair and got up infront of the sink and began washing. She then handed each dish to Michael, who carefully dried them before handing them to Peter who put them away.
Seeing that thing were under control, Wendy went back to her office. It was remarkable how this young man made such a impact on their lives so quickly and she still didn't know much about him, such as his work experience.

"Mom," Wendy looked from her screen to see Brooke in her nightgown, ready for bed standing in the doorway, holding her hand was Michael who was also in his pajamas and clutching a tattered blue blanket.
"Peter told us to come and say 'good night'"
Mary always had trouble getting the kids to go to bed, yet here Peter had them going almost willingly.
"Good night, dears."
Wendy watched the kids turn and walk away. Michael seemed tired and shuffled along slightly behind his sister.
Peter is at the top of the stairs waiting for them.
"Tell us another story." Brooke asks.
"A Pirate story. " Michael adds.
"Tomorrow." Peter says as he ushers them into their rooms.
"You better leave Michael's light on." Brooke tells Peter.
"Why?"
"Michael's afraid of the dark."
Peter begins to tell Michael of the wonders found in the night sky.

Wendy shut down her computer and she thought she saw some movement in the shadows of the hallway.
"Peter is that you?" she called out.
"Yes, ma'am." He peered around the corner and even in the dim light his eyes sparkled like green emeralds.
"We need to talk." Wendy says.
Peter walks in and sits on the coach opposite the large window.
"For me to pay you I need to know your address and social security number. If you want I can deposit your check into your account, but I'll need to know your bank and account number as well."
"Do you always treat your home like your office?" he asks.
"I'm serious. If you want to get paid I need to know these things."
"I don't have them."
"What do you mean you don't have them?"
"I just got here so I don't have an address yet."
"I'm sorry. You can stay here till you find a place. Now I'll need your social security number so I can report you salary to the IRS."
"Never got one."
"Then how did you get paid at your previous jobs?" she asks.
Peter gets up and walks to the window as the moonlight falls across his face Wendy can see the freckles across his nose. For some reason in this light he seems younger than he did before.
"Never had any that paid before."
Wendy begins questioning Peter's abilities to care for he children."Then how can you have experience raising children?"
"You don't have to get paid for having fun."
"Life isn't always fun and games. Sometimes you have to grow up."
Peter turns back and Wendy wonders if it is her imagination or is ears slightly pointed. "But you have to have fun sometimes or life isn't worth living."
"Ok," Wendy goes to the door."It's late. Tomorrow I'll work on getting you a social security number and you can tell me more about what exactly is your experience.

1141.content:
Wendy goes to the hall closet. There she has sheets and bed linen. She selects several pieces and hands them to Peter. "If you're going to stay here your going to need these."
Peter is about to thank her when both Wendy and Peter hear a noise coming from the children's bedrooms upstairs.
"I thought you said they were asleep?" Wendy asks.
"They are. I mean they were."
Suddenly Peter Leaps forward and races to the stairs. "That's not the children." He says and begins running up the stairs.
Wendy at first watches Peter take two steps at a time as he runs up the stairs. He practically looked as if he flew, that's how quickly he disappeared.
Wendy once realizing that there's a problem begins to ascend the stairs, but she's nowhere as fast as Peter.
She reaches Brooke's room first, just as she's about to enter Peter darts out the door and into Michael's. Wendy walks into Brooke's room.
Clothing, sheets and toys are scattered everywhere. White stuffing from her little girl's pillow is softly floating from the torn pillow resting on top of the open closet door.
Wendy is worried. Where is her daughter? Then she quickly thinks, what about Michael.
She rushes out of the disheveled room and across the hall to her little boy's bedroom.
His room is upset and trashed the same as his sister's and Wendy sees that neither child is present. Peter is in the far corner of the room by the window with something cupped in his hand.
1141.title: The Children Disappear

11412.content:
Wendy looks about the room.
"Where's the children?" she asks.
"They took them."
"Who?"
"The pirates." Peter says without looking up.
This is game Peter and the children are playing, Wendy thinks to herself. "Well, tell the pirates the children need their sleep." she says jokingly.
Peter gingerly puts what ever he had in his hands on the window sill and turns to face Wendy. "This is not a game. They've been kidnapped."
"And how did they get to this house? We happen to be 2 hours away from the ocean" Wendy asks.
"They came by flying pirate ship."
"A flying pirate ship." She turned to leave, "Tell the kids I want their rooms cleaned and for them to go right to sleep after they are done. And no more games!"
"Why don't you believe me?" Peter pleaded.
Wendy turned around, "Because there are no pirates and no pirate ship can fly."
Wendy was about to turn again to leave when a bright light on the window sill caught her attention.
What is it?

11412112.content:
Peter walks about the room, his steps becoming lighter and more youthful.Suddenly he spins around with his hands perched on his hips and looks at Wendy.
"If storybook villains are kidnapping real children, then there must be something diabolical they're after?" he then cups his chin in his hand and turns away again,"Hmm."
"Why Brooke and Michael?" Wendy asks again.
"Maybe it's something they have?" Peter asks.
"What could that be? They have nothing no other children have." Wendy says. "Even less because they don't have a father."
"I've got it!" Peter leaps and seemingly flies onto the bed. "It's their imagination they're after. And it's all real children. Brooke and Michael are only the start!"
Peter grabs Wendy's arm and drags her to the open window. "We've got to go!"
"Out the window?" Wendy asks.
"We've got to fly!"
"Fly?"
"Com'on it's easy!" Peter stands on the windowsill. "You just think of a wonderful thought."
"It's not that simple, Peter." Wendy says sitting down on the bed.
"Of course." He says. Then after a moment of thought, "Tinkerbell! Pixie dust!"
The little fairy flies about Peter and shimmering sparkles float down and cover him. Before Wendy's eyes Peter grows younger. As his stature changes and he becomes shorter, his red hair becomes longer and more unkempt, peeking through his hair are his ears which seem to grow pointed. His clothing changes and he looks more like the little boy that he is pictured as in books, movies and TV.
"Now that's better." He says.
"But I still can't fly." Wendy reminds him.
"Aww Wendy. Think of some happy things."

114121121.content:
Wendy awakes to blinding sunlight beaming into her tired eyes. She must have fallen asleep, but then she remembers what had happened. Looking around she finds that she is not in her home but rather laying in a beach chair on a white sand beach beside a man made swimming hole. The swimming hole has several wooden slides and an old rope swing. The scene looks like something out of a Tom Sawyer story.
Standing between the trees near by is a familiar looking boy in green tunic. The familiar red hair reminds Wendy of the events of the previous night. Cautiously she stands and walks over to Peter.
"They're here." he says sensing her approach. "We're gonna find them, I promise."
"I know." Wendy says believing him fully.
He turns and looks up at her, his eyes sparkle like green crystals, "They are probably holding them in the pirate caves."
"Where are the caves? Peter." she asks.
"Over there." Peter points across a huge blue lake towards a familiar magical castle.
"Peter," Wendy shakes her head. "this is Walt Disney World, not Neverland."
"Wendy, Neverland is the most magical place known. Can you imagine a more magical place than this." Peter then takes Wendy's hand. Slowly he begins to change, growing taller and more mature, his ears change becoming less elfin.
"The park will be opening soon, we got to go."

11412112121.content:
Brooke reached out and hugged her brother. While she held him she watched Hook go over to the desk and pull out a yellowed paper that looked like it may have been a map. His attention is quickly and intensely drawn to what was on the paper that he doesn't pay attention to the two children.
Michael begins to shake, Brooke assumes that he's frighten and holds him tighter. Then she hears him snickering quietly.
"Michael what's wrong?" she whispers.
"He's tickling me!"
Brooke is about to ask who was tickling him when she spies a tiny well dressed man standing on Michael's shoulder.
"Cricket, Jiminy Cricket's the name." The tiny green man says sweeping his top hat from his head and bowing slightly. "We're going to make sure nothing bad happens to you."
"Do you know what's going on?" Brooke asks.
"We're not sure exactly, but we've been watching the villains plotting for months." He says, "You're not the first children they've kidnapped, but you are the first that they allowed to remain awake. The other children are below in the galley, asleep."
11412112121.title: Jiminy Cricket

114121122.content:
Elsewhere, Brooke and Michael struggled against their bonds in the dark. But there was no escape. Why would somebody do this to them? Wendy had told the children stories before, about men and women who would kidnap children and do horrible things to them, but they never believed it would really happen. Michael began to struggle again, but after a few fruitless minutes, he sighed and his shoulders shook as he began to sob quietly. Brooke felt out for his hand. She found it and grasped it firmly.
"We'll be okay Michael. Peter will come and rescue us soon. Remember what he said? He said that no matter what happens, he will always be there to save us. He promised. Do you remember?"
Brooke saw the dim outline of Michael nod. She sighed sadly. Would Peter save them though?...
114121122.title: Elsewhere

13.content:
An uneventful week passed, and Wendy handed over Peter's first paycheck. "Thank you, M'am." Peter tipped his hat to the children's mother.
"I suppose I misjudged you." Wendy smiled at the redhead. "Brooke and Michael have nothing but raving reviews about you. Thank you for looking after the kids."
Peter returned the smile. "No worries, Miss. I enjoy it. They're a pleasure to look after. Angels, even."
"Well, I'm glad to hear it. Actually, Peter, I need to go to a business conference tomorrow night. I was wondering if you'd be able to look after them overnight."
"Yeah, sure, of course." Peter beamed. "I'd love to."
"Thank you so much." Wendy shook her head. "I know this was last minute and all, so I really appreciate it."
"Of course, Ms. Dearly. It's no problem, at all. Absolutely no problem."
The following night, Ms. Dearly gathered her children for a talk. "Now, follow Peter's instructions, okay, children? He will look after you tonight and tomorrow night, and I'll come back the morning after."
Brooke squeezed her mother. "I'll miss you, Mommy!"
"I'll miss you, too." Ms. Dearly hugged her son as well. "Behave, okay?"
"Yes, Mother." Michael rolled his eyes.
Peter rested an arm on each child as Ms. Dearly left. "Bye! We'll see you in two days!" He shut the door. "You ready for some fun? I'm going to teach you two how to fly!"
"Flying's impossible." Michael frowned.
"It is if that's how you think." Peter replied. "Just you wait until we get back to your bedroom. You'll see."
"This will be fun!" Brooke exclaimed. "I wanna fly, just like a fairy."
"That won't be too hard." Peter grinned. "Now, close your eyes," he instructed. "You, too, Michael."
The older boy sighed and closed his eyes.
"Now repeat after me: 'I believe I can fly.'"
"I believe I can fly," Brooke murmured.
"I believe I can fly." Michael repeated in a deadpan.
"Keep saying it," Peter encouraged, "'I believe I can fly.'"
"I believe I can fly," Brooke repeated. "I believe I can fly." She felt her body lighten up. "I believe I can fly!" She squealed as she felt her body rise. "I'm flying, I'm flying!"
"I believe I can fly," Michael tried again, a little more enthusiastically once he heard his sister's excitement. He thought about the many things he could do as a flying boy, and as he repeated the five words, he felt his body rise up, following his sister's example.
"Now, open your eyes."
The bedroom looked rather different from the ceiling, Michael observed. Brooke seemed too involved with her flying to notice the difference.
"Now, follow my lead." Peter opened the bedroom window, and checking outside to make sure nobody was watching, soared into the sky.
"Whoa! We can fly in the sky?" Brooke gasped.
"Just don't tell your mother." Peter winked. "It'll be our little secret."
With that, he flew off into the night sky, with Brooke and Michael trailing close behind him.

When she hires a young man to watch her kids, she never expected that he would fill their imaginations with stories of pirates, princess, adventures, excitement and a magical land of fantasy and reality. The man she has hires is Peter Banting and he is also the boy who never grew up. He is the real Peter Pan and soon he is wisking the kids to the real neverland, the place of Magic, DISNEY WORLD.
